Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Identifiability Optimization in Electrochemical Battery Systems

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration: This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) Program award is to examine the identifiability of electrochemical battery model parameters, defined as the degree to which one can quickly, uniquely, and accurately determine these parameters from experimental data. The research will build on previous research by the PI in battery parameter identification. The first goal is to explore different metrics for quantifying identifiability. The research will also develop algorithms for estimating both the internal state variables (e.g., degree to which a given battery is full or empty) and parameters (e.g., degree to which a battery is healthy or unhealthy) of lithium-ion batteries from experimental data. Together, these two contributions will serve as foundations for identifiability optimization. Critical information to be acquired in identifiability optimization include: the type of of sensors to be install on a lithium-ion battery to improve the detection speed and accuracy of its health degradation and the type of laboratory cycling experiments that can yield the greatest amount of information about battery model parameters with minimal time and cost.<br/><br/>The research will have broader impact on multiple societal stakeholders. Society at large will benefit from improvements in online battery diagnostics enabled by improvements in battery parameter identifiability. Battery experimentalists will be able to obtain more accurate parameters from shorter, less expensive laboratory tests. The scientific community will benefit from the efforts to bridge current gaps among electrochemistry, online estimation, and optimal control literature. Finally, the effort will focus on outreach and education activities including: (i) the engagement of undergraduate students, especially women and underrepresented minorities through Penn State University's Schreyer Honors College; (ii) the creation of web-based courses in the areas of battery system dynamics and control; (iii) the engagement of industrial partners through complementary research efforts funded by agencies such as ARPA-E; and (iv) the creation of battery-focused educational materials for K-12 STEM outreach.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined the problem of estimating the parameters of a lithium-ion battery from experimental data. This is a problem of significant societal importance, given the growing use of lithium-ion batteries for both stationary and portable energy storage as well as the difficulty of estimating battery parameters from experimental data. The project provided experimental confirmation that optimizing the manner in which a battery is tested or cycled in the laboratory can improve the speed and accuracy with which its parameters are estimated. The project has also shed light on the fact that parameter estimation errors predicted by the tool of Fisher information analysis may be smaller than the errors resulted from battery model simplification. Significant improvements in battery condition estimation were obtained when additional capacitive energy storage elements were included as additional "series sensors" in a battery pack. Moreover, the mathematical tool of Pontryagin analysis was used for gaining a better understanding of the nature of the test protocols that maximize battery parameter identifiability - i.e., the manner in which these protocols perform battery cycling, and why this helps improve identifiability. The fundamental framework furnished by this project is broadly applicable in many different practical problem domains. To illustrate this broad applicability, much of the research on this project extended beyond lithium-ion batteries to either new, emerging battery chemistries (e.g., the lithium-sulfur chemistry) or new problems in mathematical biology (e.g., the problem of estimating drug resistance in cancerous tumors), or other undergraduate research problems (e.g., the problem of estimating the inertia of a heavy-duty vehicle). 

The project has provided significant training opportunities to at least 10 graduate and undergraduate students, for at least a portion of their studies. Two of these students' Ph.D. dissertations are based predominantly on the research discoveries made through this project. One of these students won the Best Student Paper Award at the 2020 ASME Dynamic Systems and Control Conference based on research supported by this project. The PI has also significantly revamped a combined undergraduate/graduate battery systems course at The University of Maryland to include research outcomes supported by this project. 


Last Modified: 07/20/2021
Modified by: Hosam Fathy
